_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Prairie Farms Holland, IN Facility is proud to inform all interested parties that our company is complying with OSHA's Process Safety Management Standard (PSM), Title 29 Code of Federal Regulations 1910.119, and EPA's Risk Management Program regulations (RMP), Title 40 CFR Part 68. In addition to other state and local codes applicable to our facility and process. We maintain this process to deal with the risks involved with the storage, handling, and use of Anhydrous Ammonia in our facility.



Our goal is to promote overall worker, public, and plant safety. The Prairie Farms Holland, IN Facility is located at 304 W. Main St. Holland, IN. We manufacture dairy products. The facility has processing tanks, piping, packaging equipment, raw materials warehousing, finished goods refrigerated storage, an Ammonia refrigeration engine room, boilers, and miscellaneous utilities. 



The facility refrigeration system required for our production process necessitates the submission of this Risk Management Plan. The refrigeration system contains approximately 10,400 pounds of anhydrous ammonia. This surpasses the threshold quantity of 10,000 pounds outlined in Process Safety Management and Risk Management Program regulations.



Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies.



Prairie Farms - Holland has implemented numerous policies and procedures to enable our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences of significant releases of Anhydrous Ammonia as well as other hazardous substances, fires, explosions, and other types of catastrophic accidents. Overall these programs prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, illnesses, avoid property damage, and offsite impacts.  Our safety programs prevent accidents because they focus on the rules, procedures, and practices, which govern individual processes, activities, or pieces of equipment. These rules are detailed and improved as necessary. They are also communicated to and accepted by all emplo

yees at our facility.



The Prairie Farms has developed and implemented a Process Safety / Risk Management Program and has organized the information and polices pertaining to the process into a complete library. 



Volume 1 of the PSM/RMP Library incorporates several policies. Many policies are included in Volume 1, the remaining are referenced from other training manuals maintained in the facility.



Employee Participation Guidelines: This policy outlines the commitment between management and employees to establish a program for a successful (safe) program.



Process Safety Information: This includes information on the ammonia inventory at the facility, applicable codes, design standards, and information pertaining to the hazards of ammonia (referenced from the IIAR ammonia Data Book).



Process Hazard Analysis Program: This program outlines a thorough, orderly, systematic approach for identifying, evaluating, and controlling potential hazards within a process involving potentially hazardous chemicals such as ammonia.



Operating Procedures: develop, implement, and maintain clearly written, detailed procedures, guidelines, rules, and practices for the safe operation of the ammonia refrigeration process during all operating phases. The operating procedures provide all employees involved in the operation and maintenance of the ammonia refrigeration process with the written information and precautions necessary to safety perform their tasks in a consistent manner.



Contractor Qualification Guidelines: This guideline has been established to verify that the contractors working in the facility are qualified to work on the system, trained in the hazards associated with their work, and made aware of the hazards presented by the facility to the employees of the contractor.



Management of Change and Pre-Startup Safety Review Programs: These programs have been developed to monitor and provide a "checks and balances" system to monitor changes in the facility and to v

erify that changes are safe and consistent with company policy.



Mechanical Integrity Program: To prevent or minimize the consequences of catastrophic releases of ammonia, it is important to ensure process equipment is maintained properly. The purpose of an MI program is to maintain process equipment so that a catastrophic release of ammonia is avoided or properly contained. The emphasis should be on preventive maintenance rather than breakdown maintenance.



Many more specific programs and policies (Hot Work, Confined Space, Lockout / Tagout, Employee training, etc..) have been developed.



Procedures for conducting Compliance Audits, Mechanical Integrity Inspections, and Process Hazard Analyses have also been developed.



Process Hazard Analysis 5 Year Re-validation was completed on January 06, 2017.  The PHA highlighted some deficiencies in the system. These items were addressed as part of the continuous improvement of the facility. These items were addressed based on priority (Injuries to personnel).



The facility has developed Process and Instrumentation Diagrams for the individual system components. Flow schematics are included showing the entire system. A Block Flow Diagram provides a brief overview of the system. Drawings are included showing symbol and abbreviation descriptions. Plan views are included to allow the operator to physically locate equipment in the building.



The  facility has a complete set of standard operating procedures, describing the proper steps for preparing components for start-up, starting components, monitoring normal operation of system components, shutting down components as part of normal operation, restarting equipment as part of normal operation, shutting down equipment for maintenance, restarting equipment after maintenance, shutting down equipment in emergency situations, restarting equipment after an emergency situations shutdown, and pumpout procedures. Also included as a part of each Standard Operating Procedure is

the Technical Operating Specifications for the associated system component. This information includes consequences of deviation from standard operating procedures.



The facility has Manufacturer's Operation and Maintenance Information including manufactures information, spare parts list, maintenance procedures, and preventive maintenance procedures.



Prairie Farms-Holland also incorporates additional safety items such as tagging and labeling of all ammonia system valves and components.



PROCESS DESCRIPTION



Prairie Farms - Holland, IN Facility produces fluid dairy products (well cows produce the products we enhance them). Our processes involve milk based products consumed by our friends and family every day.



5 YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



The Prairie Farms Milk Processing has had no reportable releases at our facility in the last 5 years.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN: (Crisis Management Plan)



Prairie Farms has established an in-house Crisis Management Plan to quickly react to releases of Anhydrous Ammonia. The facility has established annual retraining for all personnel in Emergency Action Procedures for Ammonia with in the Crisis Management Plan.

In the event of an ammonia leak, associates should report the leak immediately to a supervisor. All other associates should be kept away from the affected area.





In the event of an evacuation the supervisor will announce the ammonia leak, the location in the building on the intercom so associates can evacuate away from the ammonia. Associates will attempt to turn off their machines if there is no immediate danger in doing so. Supervisors will check the bathrooms and lunch room before exiting the building. 





All associates shall go to the assembly area where they are to remain until released by the Emergency Response Coordinator. Emergency Response Coordinator shall designate an associate from that area to notify the fire department, Safety Manager and other emergency responders from the outside of the fac

ility. 





Each department supervisor is responsible for accounting for his/her personnel and reporting to the senior management representative present. The visitor book from the front desk should be brought out by office personnel and all visitors must be accounted for. Supply drivers will be checked to be certain they are by their truck or are signed out to be off the premises. 





No associate shall re-enter the facility until given permission by Emergency Response Coordinator. Attempts to rescue anyone trapped in the facility will be done by fire department personnel only. 



Basic first aid will be provided at the assembly area until fire department personnel can take over any injured persons. 





For more details see Supervisory Duties in Emergency Evacuation or the Process Safety Management manuals. 





All Prairie Farms responders will have an annual full face respirator fit test and a pulmonary test. 

Any Responses requiring Hazmat (300 PPM) we will evacuate building and call in an Outside Hazmat team.





PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



The Prairie Farms Inc. is committed to continuous improvement of our policies, procedures, and facility. It is the intention of The Prairie Farms to remain an industry leader. New technology, training techniques, and equipment are continuously being added to our system as they become available.
